captions.text:
Good morning, John. So, I am headed off to
Miami tomorrow morning at six o'-freakin'-clock

in the morning. I will be there in Miami;
I will do a show first. There's only 50 tickets

left and we're not selling 'em at the door,
so you have to buy them online in the next
24 hours or you're done.

And then, the morning after that concert I
will be getting up at... really early —

like, 4:00 my time — to go to Haiti. Which
reminds me, because it is now two days before
my trip, I need to go take my malaria medication.
[package snaps open]

Hopefully this will not cause, uh, dizziness
or nausea or hallucinations like they say
they could, 'cause that would suck.

I got these things at the "travel doctor,"
and she said to me, "I have good news: the

malaria that they have in Haiti is — is
the killer strain."

And of course, I'm like, "I agree with you
that that is... news."

But apparently that is a good thing, because
the kind of malaria that kills you is also

the kind of malaria that these always work
against. So that's good.

So John, a long, long time ago, you and I
went to the Dominican Republic, and we took

a tour with a microfinance organization. And
you can watch that video; it's deep in the

archives of Brotherhood 2.0. I will link to
it at the end of this video.

But the thing about it is that the Dominican
Republic is, like, ten times better off than

Haiti. But this is strange, because Haiti
and the Dominican Republic are on the same
small island, Hispaniola.

People do, of course, have opinions, thoughts,
ideas about this. There are three schools
of thought.

First, I'm gonna tell you about the one that
is probably the least, uh, obvious... and

that's the environment. So let's pretend like
this camera battery is Hispaniola.

So one-third of it would be Haiti, this third
over here; and the rest of it would be the

Dominican Republic. And then right here, on
the border of the two, is a giant mountain
range.

All of the warm, wet air hits, and it lands
in the Dominican Republic, and then it all

falls before it gets to the top of the mountains.
So it falls in the mountains and then it rolls

right back down off the edge of the D.R. So
what we have is a wet side and a dry side.

And water is a very important ingredient for
making most things... particularly for agriculture;
also for other industries.

This was all exacerbated by the second thing,
which was colonialism. Haiti was pretty much

France's biggest investment in the Western
Hemisphere. They really pushed it. Whereas

the Dominican Republic had about 20,000 slaves,
Haiti — a third the size with less water

The Dominican Republic was... was owned by
Spain, by the way.

The agricultural policies that they put in
place were really exploitative, ended in a

lot of deforestation, which of course ends
in more runoff, less soil, and less water
retention — all bad things for agriculture.

Haiti shucked its colonialism a lot sooner
than most of the rest of the world. And while

there was, for some time, stability in Haiti,
the story of Haiti in the 20th century is

one of the third problem: Really, really bad
government.

Military coups, civil war, war with the Dominican
Republic, military occupation by the United

States, dictators, military rule — every
bad government situation that you could think
of.

The longest period of stability was under
the Duvaliers, uh, first François and then

his son, Jean-Claude who were, as Shakespeare
would say, gigantic partially-digested lumps.

Aside from their military forces killing people
for political reasons, raping people for fun;

they, themselves, uh, took foreign aid and,
uh, all tax money and put it in their pockets.

The Duvalier reign finally ended in 1986 for
the same reason that all tyrannical dictatorships
end: the people got too hungry.

Since 1986 when the Duvalier reign ended,
there have been attempts at democracy, followed

by more military coups. And at this point,
Haiti is still trying to figure out its democratic

process and, of course, as you would expect,
the people of Haiti have very little faith
in that process.

It is not a good situation, and I dare you
to come up with a solution, because no one

can. But that, of course, does not mean that
we can't help people, at least in small ways.

And I'm excited to be a part of that and hopefully
allow you, uh, to help as well in the future.

John, I'll see you on Wednesday... except
that I won't. Because there's no Internet

in Haiti. So I'll see you whenever I get back
to the Internet. Goodbye.

I won't have time to make a video on Friday,
so I filmed one yesterday. It's about superhero

superpowers. And John, I'm gonna need you
to upload that video because clearly, not
a lot of Internet in Haiti.

comments.text:
1)  Most people in Haiti are of African descent, hence, "run by Africans." 

2)  Before any white man entered sub-Saharan Africa, there were a bunch of 
tribes/clans/groups vying for local power and brutally attacking, 
enslaving, killing one another, similar to most of the rest of the world at 
one time or another.  White people brought modern technology into Africa so 
the population could explode and they could have more effective means of 
killing one another.  The only difference between pre- and post-white-ruled 
Africa is now they don't have any sensible leaders to take care of them.  
Now we are back to the status quo in sub-Saharan Africa, but we have 
pretentious, unintelligent people regurgitating the "evils of the white 
man" without thinking objectively of the situation.  The major exception to 
the sub-Saharan disaster is South Africa, ruled mostly by whites.  No 
individual can be judged by their race, but to deny racial factors in 
populations' actions is to deny statistics.
comments.author: NichtsIstVerboten

comments.author: Thurston Lhast

comments.text:
um... Haiti was INTENTIONALLY financially ruined... The idea that enslaved 
people could successfully stage and insurrection and gain complete control 
of their own country was not one to be lauded, since it would be an 
encouraging tale for persons enslaved elsewhere. The fear was that news 
would spread of a successful revolt to the other colonies and lead to the 
forceful liberation of other territories. So, to discourage that, the 
international community put up every barrier to trade possible, held Haiti 
responsible for the debts incurred during their independence struggle ( 
which was only very recently forgiven), and watched as impoverishment 
ensued. It's sad that people neglect that part of Haiti's story which quite 
frankly speaks volumes of the international approach to former slave 
colonies. ﻿
comments.author: Johanda

development of the country.﻿

comments.author: Alysha Clarke

comments.text:
You left out the most important reason which was a direct reason that led 
to all the other problems. Haiti (Colonized by France) was the richest of 
all colonies, even richer than the US at the time of slavery. They had a 
lot more slaves than the Dominican Republic because their cash crop was 
sugar cane, which was the most demanding(labor intensive) crop but very 
profitable. More profitable than any other crop including cotton. The 
slaves were worked long and hard, in the worst conditions. Because of that 
the life span for a slaves, in rich Haiti, was very short compared to 
slaves elsewhere. Believe it or not, but the slave masters there 
intentionally worked their slaves to death(an early death). They felt it 
was more profitable to work the slaves long and hard, causing them to be 
worked to death, and just continue to replace them.

When the slaves rebelled, they won. They kicked Napoleons troops butt. So 
bad that France was almost broke and that's how the US got such a great 
deal on the Louisiana Purchase. 

With that being said, the country was being run and worked by the very 
people that knew how & did all the agricultural work(the work that already 
made Haiti the richest colony). Now of course the European and the US 
powers were not about to allow those Haitians to prosper, and those powers 
especially the US did everything in their power to sabotage, and their 
reason was(If Haiti prospered it would put the US in a higher possibility 
of having slave revolts). The world forced Haiti to pay reparations to 
France (so much reparations that Haiti couldn't afford to pay it all). They 
put sanctions on Haiti which forced the world not to do business with 
Haiti. Not to mention all the millions of dollars Haiti was paying shipping 
companies that were supposed to be shipping goods and services from Haiti 
that was never delivered, the money was stolen and never ever giving back 
to Haiti.

So what did that cause? It caused mass poverty. The country was 
intentionally ruined. Everybody should know mass poverty leads to 
corruption, violence, crime,  a break down of society, and no ability to 
have law in order. Everything I just said is verifiable.       ﻿

dreams, bouts of psychosis, and potential long-term neurological changes

of). On the other hand, Malarone (as I believe Hank was taking), 
doxycycline, and others have a less dramatic side-effects.

comments.author: Eric Sandin

comments.text:
Hank I am utterly disappointed by you statement that "No one can find a 
solution." I love Haiti and I plain on finding a solution. In the time I 
spent in Haiti I found that the biggest problems were one the overly 
corrupt government, but the most severe problem was the peoples lack of 
foresight, they would cut down fruit trees to burn and then have nothing to 
eat. Also do you read all of the comments?
comments.author: Cole Hartzler

when you showed the picture of Hispanola.

comments.author: Abhinav Madahar

comments.text:
(2) This elite has also worked in conjunction with exploitation by the 
world's superpowers and their corporations (France, Canada, US). Haitians 
fight very hard for democracy and they achieved a great period of that 
during the 1990's under Pres. Aristide, and things have taken a major nose 
dive since he was overthrown in a coup in 2004.
comments.author: ayana2003

comments.text:
(1) This video is interesting. It's a good start to talking about what's 
going on in Haiti and very informative for those who don't know about it. I 
am Haitian and I have to stress an extremely important point that was left 
out: Haiti is not missing out on democracy because Haitians don't know how 
to have successful democracy, it has been thwarted by political oppression 
from a ruling, exploitative elite.
comments.author: ayana2003

comments.author: NicoTheSecondDoctor

comments.text:
I think we should give 21st century colonies or mandates a go. Like a pro 
bono thing. Get a few world superpowers to take ownership of tiny poor 
places and make them better. Ensure democratic and advisable governments, 
military bases and training camps, foreign investors, hospitals and, of 
course, schools. If Haiti became the 51st state it would be far better off, 
perhaps at the minor expense the mainland. then again Haiti has a 
population of just under 10 million so it isn't very big

comments.author: shelbybroaddus

comments.text:
You have missed the fact that after Haiti got rid of it's colonial rulers 
France got annoyed and blockaded Haiti and pretty much starved them. They 
then said that Haiti could have their freedom if they paid compensation for 
each slave. This was paid to France even after WWII. This made them very 
poor. Thumbs up this so people can see
comments.author: Tyron Surmon

comments.text:
FUN FACT in the game Assassins Creed the Haitian dictator François Duvalier 
who ruled Haiti from 1957 until his death in 1971. The true cause of his 
death was that he actually taken out by an Assassin!! No I'm not kidding 
fellow Assassins Creed fans will remember he was featured in a puzzle 
showing targets throughout history Assassins had taken out. Its interesting 
to imagine that in the world of Assassins creed there's actually a 
Assassins Guild in Haiti!
